data.title: Language capabilities and URI schemas

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

# Language Capabilities and URI schemas

## Current situation

Documents in VS Code are currently classified using two dimensions:

- the language mode: It determines the programming language used. Examples are: TypeScript, JavaScript, HTML, ...
- the document source, expressed using the schema of the documents URIs. Examples are: file, inmemory, untitled, git, ...

The features set usually offered on a document depends on a combination of these two. For example a TypeScript file stored on disk (having the schema `file`) should offer the full TypeScript feature set like diagnostics, code complete, document symbols or find all references. In contrast a TypeScript file loaded from a git index (schema `gitindex` not 100% sure about the schema name) should not provide code complete since the file is read only. Even diagnostics are questionable since users can't fix them. However document symbols are useful to navigate in large files loaded from a git index.

Currently the feature set offered doesn't take the schema into account. The editor requests all features per language mode and then disables features if the document is read-only (this is why there is no code complete on files loaded from the git index).

However binding features to the read-only characteristic of a document can be conflicting: a prominent example are diagnostics. They are not very useful on files loaded from the git index, especially if errors are caused through inter file dependencies. However showing diagnostic for a read only file on disk does make sense since fixing the problem might be possible by changing another non read-only file.

## Ideas

To handle these cases correctly VS Code could offer a capability registry for URI schemas. The extension that brings a new URI schema into the system describe the language capabilities that usually make sense on that form of URI. However it is unclear how fine grain that registry should be. One approach would be to list all language capabilities currently available in the extension API. Drawback being that when we introduce new capabilities users need to either opt in or opt out. If we use opt in then at least extension don't need to be changed if a new capability is introduce. Alternatively we can describe capability sets. Something like:

- Diagnostics: it makes sense to compute diagnostics on the URI schema
- Manipulating: it makes sense to provide features that manipulate the document. For example code complete, rename, ...
- Structural: it makes sense to support feature that provide structural information about the document. For example document symbols
- Navigational: it makes sense to support features that help navigate documents. For example: goto declarartion
- Searching: it makes sense to support feature that search for symbols. For example: find all references

There is another dimension that is interesting. Language modes that are single file (like HTML) and language modes that are multi file (like TypeScript and C#) where inter file dependencies matter. Providing navigational and searching features on multi file language modes loaded from the git index for example might be confusing for users since most language server will only compute the result for that single file only. However navigating or searching for local symbols (like goto declaration of a local variable) do make sense.

If we introduce such a capability register do we need to enforce the correct behavior. We have the following possibilities:

- we enforce only the read-only ness of a document (this is what we do today)
- we enforce the capabilities as well. If for example an extension computes diagnostics for a URI schema that doesn't list the capability we drop the diagnostics.
- we treat the capabilities has a hint and extensions / language providers need to honor them.

## Proposal

I propose that we implement such a schema capability registry. Contributions to the registry can be done via code or the package.json file. The registry can be queried in the render and the extension host. A query passes in a schema or a URI and answers back the suggested capabilities. We should not enforce the honoring of the capabilities beside the read-only ness. It will unnecessarily hinder innovation. I would go with the above 5 capabilities. But reducing them to Diagnostics, Manipulating, 'Non-Manipulating' (may be someone has a better name) would address all use case I am are currently aware of.

data.title: The terminal process command "C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe" failed to launch (exit code: 1)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Control + `
2. The terminal process command "C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe" failed to launch (exit code: 1)

I'm aware that non-ascii characters in path may probably produce this issue, there is NO non-ascii characters in the path

This problem starts to occur once updated to version 1.9

Won't work after reinstalling VS Code

data.title: Custom keybinding have different priority then default keybindings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `1.9.1`
- OS Version: `Windows 10`

Steps to Reproduce:

Default scenario:  

Default keybinding:
`{ "key": "f11", "command": "workbench.action.toggleFullScreen" }`

1. Using default keybindings, enter debug mode and stop on a breakpoint.
2. Press `f11`
3. Debugger steps into

Custom keybinding scenario
`{ "key": "f11", "command": "workbench.action.toggleZenMode" }`  

1. Using custom keybindings, enter debug mode and stop on a breakpoint.
2. Press `f11`
3. Enter ZenMode (But I wanted to step into)

Workaround:

Add `"when": "!inDebugMode"` condition.

But the default keybinding doesn't have `"when": "!inDebugMode"` condition, so why does the custom keybinding need it?

data.title: Change all occurrences works for first 1000 entries only
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with same word present multiple times( > 2000).
2. Select some part of word and right click -> change all occurrences. Only selects first 1000 entries.

data.title: [Enhance]Minimap enhancement with some features!

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (50f8848e44029ffabf0727de49cd18ae4069b4fe, 2017-02-17T13:43:37.461Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
First, the minimap is really useful and exciting feature added recently. 
But there are some enhancements:
one: migrate minimap and scrollbar when minimap enabled, this will make the right part of editor looks simple but powerful.
two: git status in minimap. this would a good feature for people find which parts of code has changed quickly.
three:  make the gray block to identify position of a file more gray.

data.title: showTextDocument() should allow to set { pinned: false }
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `1.10.0-insider` 50f8848e44029ffabf0727de49cd18ae4069b4fe
- OS Version: macOS Sierra `10.12.3 (16D32)`

The `vscode.open` command seems to be the only way to open a document in a "preview" tab, but currently it steals focus. While `window.showTextDocument` doesn't have an option to show in a "preview" tab (might be a nice option as well), but does support `preserveFocus?: boolean`.

So right now, from an extension I can't seem to open a document in a preview tab, but also not steal focus.

As an example, I was attempting to open documents in a preview tab while using the `onDidSelectItem` event from `showQuickPick()`.

English | Not proper | Proper

data.title: Completions in watches
data.body: Suggestion: we could wire up the intellisense window for completions that we have in the debug console to also show up when adding a watch. Other tools do this

data.title: [git] Add extension api event for when a file is commit
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `1.10.0-insider` 50f8848e44029ffabf0727de49cd18ae4069b4fe
- OS Version: macOS Sierra `10.12.3 (16D32)`

I would love to be able to listen for an event for when the a file in an open editor has been committed. Currently we have api events for when a document changes and is saved, but nothing for when a document is commit.

Specifically this would help out GitLens, to where I could avoid issues where the blame continues to show "Uncommitted changes" because I haven't detected that the file has been committed.

data.title: [frature] expose api to run single file or project
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.10.0-insider (50f8848e44029ffabf0727de49cd18ae4069b4fe, 2017-02-17T13:43:37.461Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0

Now vscode can easily debug project, or single file(with extension support), but for a single file or project, there looks no way to run it. In sometimes run is more useful than debug. 
A suggestion, expose `CMD+r` to run a single file use language default build tool, for python , user can set use python2 or python3 and add some command line variables through config file, for go, default use `go run ${currentFile}` also with more command line variables defined in config file.

data.title: Feature request: Incremental / emacs style search/find

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature request:

Need to have incremental/Emacs style search.
When activated, it allows you to type in search term and on the fly searches through current document as you type. At any point reactivating it via key binding should skip to the next occurrence. Also have a incremental prev search key binding that goes the prev occurrence.

data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1018196/23088235/5f88a916-f52f-11e6-9843-52c63cf4f1bd.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1018196/23088261/b8aa16c4-f52f-11e6-8503-c22b5f170aec.png)


Some sort of filter functionalaity like chrome devtools console or F12 console allowing one to filter errors/log/info would be nice. Being able to just see errors would drastically reduce signal to noise ratio when fixing unexpected js exceptions.

data.title: Markdown Preview Suggestion
data.body:
Hi there. Just a friendly drop in the suggestion box:

One of the biggest pain points I've had in VS Code is how markdown preview works.

Currently, if a user has a dark theme selected, then the markdown preview will render in a dark style. Period. Even with custom CSS set.

I'm a huge proponent for dark themes for code, but I'd prefer to personally read markdown the same way as it will read on Github, Gitlab, etc (with a light theme).

As of right now, I'm finding myself using VS Code for everything -- except markdown -- for this very reason. It's really the only reason I have atom still installed on my machine.

Thanks for considering!

data.title: GoToDefinition doesn't scroll to the top of the blue definition UI
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1 and 1.10.0-insiders
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I'm using a high DPI laptop (not sure if that's required).
2. Cause the Problems/etc. pane to appear and split the UI 50%.
3. Use Go to (Peek) Definition using any language that supports it.

Bug: See the screenshot. The blue "definition" box is not scrolled up to the top, which is really annoying when the document is large and it's hard to scroll up by a small amount to see the definition options on the right. The repro seems 100% when the UI is sufficiently constrained. I need to see the top because that's where the definition list is (when things are defined in multiple places).

Bug#2: The lack of the top/bottom arrow buttons makes it hard to scroll up/down by single lines when the document is large, and using the keyboard to go up lines doesn't work if the keyboard cursor is stuck in the blue box.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19859882/23085789/763027fe-f51e-11e6-9a95-9029e8bb7e57.png)

data.title: Quality of Life Suggestion: open files in the same window
data.body:
I have 5 untitled files in hot exit (I leave them there as memos). When I open a file without Code opened, the file opens in a window separate to the hot exit files. It would be great to unify the windows when a file is being opened.
Demonstration:
![2017-02-17_21-46-08](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21363469/23084530/a0a838a0-f55a-11e6-9b15-7e7064e74dae.gif)

data.title: JSDocs toolip not showing for classes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a class with JSDocs associated with the class definition
2. Import the class to a file ie
`import MyClass from "./MyClass";`

When hovering over the class variable the only docs provided are 'import MyClass' which isn't that helpful. However the JSDocs for the class ie that which explains the purpose of the class are missing. JSDocs show up fine for any methods defined on the class. While I get its an alias, it would be very helpful to have these docs show up when hovering over the name.

data.title: Quick open: Editor history selection lost once file results kick in
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: `1.10.0-insider` 50f8848e44029ffabf0727de49cd18ae4069b4fe
- OS Version: macOS Sierra `10.12.3 (16D32)`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the command palette
2. Start typing a couple of characters of something in the recently opened section
3. Quickly use the arrow keys to move down on the list like you are going to select one of the items in the recently opened section
4. Notice as soon as the auto-complete section below the recently opened section fill out, the selected item will move back to the first item in the list -- instead of staying where it was

It took me a bit to figure out the scenario here, because I just kept noticing that when I'd start searching for something, see it on the recent list, select it and open it -- but it kept opening the wrong file. And it was because the selection was getting reset *just* before I hit enter, so I ended up opening the wrong file.
